The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some controversy. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The present paper provides a categorical approach to quantum mechanics that is independent of any analytical structure. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The approach is based on the category of Hilbert spaces and continuous linear operators. The category of Hilbert spaces is equivalent to the category of probability spaces and linear operators that preserve the probability measure. This provides a mathematical foundation for quantum mechanics that is independent of any analytical structure. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been enigmatic, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to a minimal structure, and that the genome is one of the smallest reported in animals. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This is consistent with the hypothesis that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the Cnidaria. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The current pandemic is caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The virus has a high mutation rate and is constantly evolving. This study focuses on the role of the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2 in the evasion of the host antiviral response. We show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and blocks nuclear import of importin/karyopherin, which is essential for the transport of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) to the nucleus. We also show that Orf6 binds to the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is essential for the docking of the importin/karyopherin complex at the NPC. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host antiviral response. This knowledge could be used to develop new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton (Hv1) channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 by binding to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This will increase the instability of global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. The results also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is critical to understanding the mechanisms of species coexistence in ecosystems. However, identifying the species-level composition of diets has been challenging, and the extent to which different species partition food resources has been difficult to quantify. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that the species-level identification of diets is possible, and that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of using DNA metabarcoding to identify species-level diet composition in future studies of trophic interactions. This article is protected by copyright. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses between March 28 and April 4, 2020. The survey asked about the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on business operations and financial health. We find that many small businesses are already experiencing layoffs and closures. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the likely duration of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is still a matter of debate. Some authors suggest that SiC grains are presolar, i.e., they formed in the interiors of stars. However, the ages of presolar SiC grains are unknown. Here, we present the ages of 40 large presolar SiC grains from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We determined the ages of the grains by measuring the exposure ages of the produced cosmogenic nuclides Ne-21 and 3He-3. The ages range from 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This suggests that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. Our results provide evidence for a significant role of the interstellar medium in the formation of presolar SiC grains

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million more motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Reproductive output is a fundamental measure of the success of a species. In this study, we examine the effect of different forms of external energy supplementation on reproductive output. We find that domestication and all forms of allocare correlate with increased fertility. All forms of provisioning correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase we observe in reproductive power is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output and the potential for human-assisted reproductive technologies. This article is protected by copyright. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be of great importance for MSA patients, who currently have no treatment. Our results also open the door to the use of VX-765 in other synucleinopathies. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform a variety of functions. The endothelium is connected to each other and to the surrounding cells by a network of cells. The network is critical for the endothelium to communicate with the surrounding cells and to coordinate the vascular function. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide open access to data that can be used to track the pandemic and inform public health policy. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. An allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this Threonine residue is essential for the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter on activation. This structural change is the basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This work provides a structural explanation for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural basis for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter. This work is expected to be of interest to the general scientific community and to the pharmaceutical industry. (Show more)

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system that is influenced by the host and the environment. The anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gut are a largely unexplored source of natural products that could be used to modulate the microbiome. This study provides a resource of anaerobic fungal natural products and a framework for future studies of the biosynthesis of these compounds. This work also highlights the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce antimicrobial compounds that could be used to treat infections caused by antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. However, the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is of great significance for the development of functional devices. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly strategy. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired responses. It is expected to inspire the development of functional devices with complex and navigable responses. The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in mammals. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and that it is expressed in erythroid tissues. We show that IGF2BP1 can reprogram the hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroid cells. This is accomplished by reduced expression of the adult hemoglobin genes and increased expression of fetal hemoglobin. This study suggests a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the timing of development in humans and to the hemoglobin phenotypes observed in human disease. This study also suggests a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. (Read more)

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. It is regulated by cellular metabolism, redox homeostasis, and various signaling pathways related to cancer. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are associated with heart failure, but the mechanism is not known. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling pathways that promote vascular remodeling. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in hypertension. It also provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in hypertension in combination with other drugs that target STIM/ORAI. This study may also provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP had little effect on the conservation of older-forest–associated birds, but did halt the decline of early-seral–associated birds. However, the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated birds, and the early-seral ecosystem area declined in two ecoregions. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on computational predictions of membrane permeability, binding affinity to the ribosome, and solubility. We tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach presented here is a promising tool for the rational design of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We also show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results for the problem of semantic segmentation of satellite images. This work is expected to be useful for the community of researchers working in the field of deep learning.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular. However, the biological effects of such devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) chronostratigraphic boundary is the most enigmatic of the last ∼18,000 y. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB is consistent with terrestrial sources. The Os in bulk samples and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is likely derived from the crust. The Os in 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania is likely derived from the crust. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell responses, but its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We also show that CTLA-4 deficiency has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4–deficient mice had more severe collagen-induced arthritis (CIA), they were protected against peptide-induced experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE); however, onset of protein-induced EAE was only delayed. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is complex. These findings have implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. (Read more)

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls, using 154 genomes or transcriptomes. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. These novel genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles, resulting in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that beetles diversified in response to the evolution of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. This resulted in the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning

The apoE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is involved in synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE alleles are highly dependent on each other in regulating the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, accelerating the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest and densest solid body in the solar system. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. The nucleation of the inner core is a key step of crystallization. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. We found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be different from that of the outer core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less understood. Here, we show that the brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also the most complex cognitive skill we have. How the human brain processes language is therefore a central question in cognitive science. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can do the same for the brain’s neural responses to language that they already do for words in the next-word prediction task. This suggests that the brain’s language system operates via predictive processing. We also find that model architecture contributes to the brain’s neural fit. These results provide computationally explicit evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They thus have implications for theories of language and learning, and for the design of artificial general intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning. However, it is still in its infancy and faces a number of challenges. One of the most fundamental challenges is that of instability. In this paper, we show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a paradox that we address by introducing a classification theory of stability. We believe that this work will help to pave the way for the future of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community has been working around the clock to understand the virus and its spread. In this context, the study of a classic experiment published 45 years ago has become a source of controversy. This article discusses the flaws of the experiment and the implications of this controversy for the study of human cognition.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. The uncultured human pathogen M. lepromatosis is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is similar to that of M. leprae but has retained the ability to infect the nervous system. Phylogenetic analyses suggest that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA than M. leprae, and a Bayesian dating analysis suggests that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 13.9 Mya. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study provides a foundation for understanding the evolution of leprosy. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science. They are also the two main ingredients of the thermodynamic formalism, which is the cornerstone of statistical mechanics. However, the relation between them is not fully understood. In this work, we unveil the full dynamics of the entanglement in the space–time scaling limit. We do so by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only currently available vaccine against COVID-19, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This study describes a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, COVI-VAC, that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is highly protective in a relevant hamster model and can be manufactured at large scale. These properties make COVI-VAC a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs. This study provides a promising approach for the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with rodent and flea transmission being the most prominent hypotheses. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the history of plague. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic of study in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain power, which is a more relevant measure of cognitive capacity, is still poorly understood. We present a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of brain neuron numbers in amniotes, which is the most fundamental unit of brain computation. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic structures that are constantly being assembled and disassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins is the major regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is therefore critical for cells to understand how to regulate the activity of ADF/cofilin in different situations. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin is more active in situations that favor filament severing, such as local curvature and mechanical tension. We propose a mechanochemical mechanism, which we verify experimentally, that explains how ADF/cofilin can be more active in these situations. This mechanism is critical for cells to understand how to regulate the activity of ADF/cofilin in different situations. (Show more)

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a popular choice for dieters. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior are not well understood. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite and a stronger trigger of feeding behavior. Understanding the effects of different sugars on brain and behavior may help inform dietary recommendations. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island suggests that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It is also a step forward in the understanding of the history of the Indian Ocean islands. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. This work shows that emotional contagion can occur in a social network setting, without the need for in-person interaction or nonverbal cues. This work also suggests that people’s positive experiences can be influenced by observing others’ positive experiences. This work has implications for understanding the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have profound effects on gene expression. In this study, we focus on one of the most common modifications found in coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ). We show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain and the activation of the elongation factor EF-Tu. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the cell. These findings suggest that the ribosome encounters Ψ in mRNA sequences in a manner that can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This study provides a better understanding of the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust over a 4-y period and are not driven by factors such as depression or prosperity. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining characteristic of aquatic mammals. We test the extent to which the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes through a quantitative analysis of the fossil and extant records of mammal body size. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes. This result is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The common cold is caused by rhinovirus, a small, nonenveloped, icosahedral virus that is the most common cause of upper respiratory tract infections. Rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at body temperature. Here, we show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings may help to identify new strategies for the development of antiviral agents for the treatment of the common cold. (Read more)

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the type IV pili of P. aeruginosa are used as a mechanosensory system to detect the presence of surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen’s ability to attach to surfaces and cause infection.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the consequences of this development for the quality of global surface waters are poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread globally and is responsible for millions of deaths. The virus has been documented in many animal species, but the extent of the spillover events and the role of animals in the ongoing pandemic are not well understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer in Iowa. We also show that the virus has spread between deer and humans. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon economy. The development of renewable energy sources is critical to this transition. Hydropower is the leading source of renewable energy. However, the proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern. This paper examines the challenges of building large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the activation of microglia, which are the principal immune cells in the brain. Here, we show that neurons, rather than microglia, are the primary source of the proinflammatory response in AD. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of the proinflammatory response in AD. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may therefore be a critical early event in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD. (Show more)

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which demonstrates that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

The cellular concentration of dinucleoside tetraphosphates, often described as alarmones, increases in response to stress. In bacteria, these molecules are capped with a nucleoside triphosphate (Np4) at their 5′ ends. Removal of this cap is critical for initiating 5′ end-dependent degradation of those RNAs, potentially affecting bacterial adaptability to stress. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression induced by sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that this depletion is associated with the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring arginine plasma levels and T cell function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon and other elements that living organisms contain. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Thus, our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and the system’s activity or “complexity” is periodic in time. The period of the activity is not fixed, but changes in time. The activity of the system is measured by the number of events that occur per unit time. The activity of the system is proportional to the inverse of the time scale. This is a very general phenomenon, which has been observed in many systems. The simplest example is a pile of sand, where the activity is the height of the pile. The height of the pile increases when more sand is added, and decreases when sand is removed. The height of the pile is proportional to the time scale. This is a continuous model. In this paper, we report on a model of SOC, which is a discrete model.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. This opens up opportunities for tailoring its properties for applications.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of plants is well established. However, the role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of plants is not well understood. The study of the evolution of plant-associated microorganisms is hampered by the lack of knowledge of the structural and functional diversity of these microorganisms. Here, we report the structure and antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide. The antifungal activity of the peptide is attributed to its ability to bind to multiple phosphoinositides in germlings, followed by penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli. This study illustrates the structural and functional diversity of the NCR peptide family and the potential of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the Drosophila sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be useful to the scientific community studying sperm–FRT interactions, sperm maturation, and the evolution of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The A1 domain in VWF binds to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on platelets. We show that force application switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of VWD mutations, explaining pathophysiology. Conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This work provides a mechanism for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD and a mechanism for using force to treat bleeding. (Read more)

The human microbiome is a rich source of information about human health and disease. However, the human virome has been difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which will enable the study of the virome in a wide range of human diseases. The database is available for download, and the results of the study are published in a series of papers.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties. The observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for more than a century. The temperature inferred from isotopic data is lower than that inferred from protein data. This discrepancy has been attributed to a variety of factors, including the possibility that the isotopic data are not representative of the surface environment. Here, we present data on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes that are compatible with the surface environment. The thermostability of these enzymes is shown to correlate with the surface environment, and the results are used to infer the surface temperature of the ancestor of each enzyme. The results are consistent with the temperature of the surface decreasing over geological time.

Potassium channels are important for the normal function of the heart, brain, and kidneys. The K+ channel KCNB1 encodes the BK channel, which is important for the normal function of the heart. The BK channel is unique in that it lacks a classic activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help to understand the BK channel’s unique properties and may provide a basis for the development of new drugs for the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 100 million cases and 200,000 deaths annually. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This would have important implications for the design of antimalarial therapies. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. This opens up opportunities for tailoring its properties for applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may inform the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus on human health. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a top-down, left-corner manner, starting with the simplest elements and gradually adding more complex ones. Here, we show that the brain encodes the merge operation, which is the key step in this process, in a distributed fashion across multiple regions of the human brain. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up or bottom-left parser to compress syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway in development and disease. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and two forms of Axin are found in vertebrates. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently in different tissues. This differential regulation may be used to control the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. This effect is blocked by optogenetic stimulation of LH neurons, suggesting that electrical stimulation is not a general property of LH neurons. Optogenetic stimulation of LH neurons also causes eating in animals that are not hungry. This suggests that LH neurons are not involved in the mechanisms that govern hunger. However, optogenetic stimulation of LH neurons causes eating in animals that are not satiated. This suggests that LH neurons are involved in the mechanisms that govern satiety. Here we show that electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes eating in animals that are not hungry and that this effect is blocked by lesions of LH neurons. This system may contribute to the development of obesity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for controlling the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley, using a bacterial signal produced by the plant. This system could be used to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in cereals, and could be extended to other crops. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a significant step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation. However, the effectiveness of these systems is limited by the time it takes for alerts to reach the most directly affected communities. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize the source of sound. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy, but all are part of the organism. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, and the spider can hear by sensing the motion of the web. The spider’s web is not constrained by the organism’s body and can be extended to increase the spider’s hearing surface area enormously. The spider can also adjust and regenerate the web according to its needs. The spider’s hearing is not constrained by the organism’s body, and the spider can hear without a body.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are well known, but the combined effects of fossil-fuel-related and anthropogenic aerosol emissions on global climate and human health are not. We estimate the climate and health benefits of reducing both types of emissions. We find that the health benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions are much larger than those of reducing anthropogenic aerosols. The combined effects of reducing fossil-fuel-related and anthropogenic aerosol emissions are even larger. Our results show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. This is a call for urgent action.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people worldwide. Vaccines are needed to contain the pandemic, but the current vaccines are not affordable for low- and middle-income countries. We report a strategy to engineer a SARS-CoV-2 RBD that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. The engineered RBD is more manufacturable, has higher affinity to ACE2, and induces a stronger immune response than the Wuhan-Hu-1 RBD. This engineered RBD can be presented on a designed VLP to reduce weight loss in hamsters. This engineered RBD can be used in combination with other vaccine platforms to accelerate the global vaccination effort. This engineered RBD can be used in combination with other vaccine platforms to accelerate the global vaccination effort. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is implicated in the development of many human cancers. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs (DrALKs) are activated by secreted ALKALs (DrALKals). The DrALKals are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. The results are important for understanding the role of ALK family RTKs in human cancers. They also provide a model system for studying the role of ALK family RTKs in neural crest development. This study is expected to contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for human cancers and neurodevelopmental disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the Yersinia pestis lineage that caused the Black Death in the 14th century is still responsible for periodic outbreaks. However, the early history of this pathogen is poorly understood. Here, we present 17 ancient Y. pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age. This dataset allowed us to explore the diversity of the pathogen during this critical period of development. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural lands is often at odds with SOC storage. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage in Mollisols, but the extent of these increases is limited by the legacy of intensive agriculture. We also show that the management of grasslands can increase SOC storage, and that this potential can be realized with rotational grazing. These findings highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses from wildlife to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be a useful tool for the global scientific community and public health practitioners.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators. However, the mechanisms that underlie the production of nectar pigments are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for the study of nectar chemistry. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 475 and 675 AD. The analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of this group indicates that women had a much more complex history than men. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides insights into the genetic history of Europe during a period of cultural change. It also demonstrates the potential of the analysis of functional variants to provide insights into the history of European populations.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origins and evolution of MERS-CoV and other bat coronaviruses, and for developing strategies to prevent and control their cross-

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid, scalable, and cost-effective diagnostics. Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a powerful tool for pathogen detection, but its application in resource-scarce settings is limited. We describe the use of mNGS in Cambodia, a resource-scarce country, to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the potential for mNGS to be deployed in a coordinated, ongoing manner to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can better inform public health response. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique view into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. This study also provides a unique view into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. The RNA world hypothesis proposes that life on Earth began with the evolution of RNA-based enzymes that replicated and converted RNA into functional molecules. In this study, we demonstrate that RNA can replicate and convert RNA into functional molecules in the absence of proteins. This is a significant step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is still in the stage of trial and error. Tocilizumab, which has been approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, is a humanized monoclonal antibody targeting the IL-6 pathways. In this study, we found that tocilizumab could reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

The role of metal homeostasis in the biology of filamentous fungi is not well understood. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for these natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. The copper-chelating properties of xanthocillin-derived isocyanides support a role for these compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides a model for the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, is a rare mineral on Earth and in the solar system. It is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is significant because it is a rare mineral on the planet and because it is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals. The tridymite is well-crystalline and formed at high temperatures. The other crystalline minerals are detrital, possibly from the crater wall/rim/central peak. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture. We show that the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new frost regimes. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Using a Th17 transfer model of colitis, we found that Th17 cells could not induce colitis in recipients lacking IFN-γ. Instead, recipients required the development of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells, which were dependent on Stat4 and T-bet. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, different clinical courses, and different mechanisms of death. The disease is also progressive, with motor neuron degeneration occurring over time. The disease is fatal, with a median survival of 2–5 y. There is a need for rapid, reproducible, and high-throughput disease modeling to identify disease mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients. This will enable high-throughput screening of potential therapeutic targets. The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma. We also show that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of the gut microbiota in pathogen transmission and the potential for therapeutic intervention. This article is protected by copyright.
