The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of vertebrates. The study of the early evolution of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and diversification of birds. Here, we report the discovery of a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group and provides insights into the origin and evolution of the avian tail. This study also highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of mosaic traits. (Show more)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. This paper shows that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is determined by the absorption spectrum of its pigments. In some species, the absorption spectrum of the pigments is modified by the presence of proteins that bind the pigments. This phenomenon is called “color modification” or “coloration.” In this study, we describe a new type of coloration, called “chlorosis,” in frogs and toads. Chlorosis is the presence of blue-green tissues and bones. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of frogs and toads.

Hypoxia is a common feature of solid tumors, and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes the growth of breast cancer are not well understood. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn promotes the growth of breast cancer cells. This study provides a mechanism for how hypoxia may promote the growth of breast cancer. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were produced from fetal skins. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of the extinction and its aftermath. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary, which is defined by the onset of the extinction. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in the regulation of various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the function of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is not well understood. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune response of the host and of the vaccine. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the receptor for SARS-CoV-2, and a human cell membrane. The structure of the spike in complex with ACE2 and the cell membrane is highly similar to the structure of the spike in complex with the cell membrane alone. This suggests that the receptor binding domain of the spike is the major determinant of the interaction with the cell membrane.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even in the case of a single player.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic will result in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and are the basis of the periodic table. The chemical properties of elements are also of great importance in the study of the Earth’s interior, the origin of life, and many other fields. In this work, we study the chemical properties of elements under pressure, which is a field of great interest. We find that chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure, and that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is of great interest to the chemistry community.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme fire events. However, the role of human ignitions and fire suppression in driving fire regimes is poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity and carbon emissions, using a coupled climate–fire–carbon cycle model. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of active fire management in reducing warming. However, the risk of more extreme fires under climate change means that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights the need for a more integrated approach to climate change mitigation, including active fire management. This is particularly important in fire-dependent ecosystems, where fire is a key ecosystem process.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is released by the host only at night, when the symbiont population is at its peak, and is catabolized by the symbionts, whose activity is enhanced by the resulting changes in the environment. This study provides a mechanism for how the provision of a single nutrient can regulate the activities of a complex microbial community. It also suggests that other animal hosts may similarly regulate the activities of their associated microbial communities through the strategic provision of specific nutrients. Text data are ubiquitous, but the latent patterns that they encode are difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Motivated by known patterns in suicide and homicide by gender and recent research on gender biases in semantic space, we identify the gender bias of our topics (e.g., a topic about pain medication is feminine). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The disease was transmitted by the flea, which feeds on the blood of infected rodents. The rodent reservoirs of the second plague pandemic are still unknown. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the second plague pandemic. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, they are also a food source for a variety of predators, including sea stars. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids have recently experienced an extensive outbreak of wasting disease. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a disease outbreak in asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor. The IL1RAP (IL1R3) is expressed on AML cells, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be relevant to other viruses, such as HIV, that mutate frequently. Our approach may be useful in other fields of medicine and biotechnology.

Crop experts are the backbone of the agricultural sector, and their knowledge is critical for the management of agricultural production. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily accessible for data-driven analysis. We propose a method to convert the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting index is robust and stable over time, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. The proposed method can be easily extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other agricultural commodities such as livestock, fisheries, and forestry.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This is a mechanism that is not reliant on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity for storage. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This mechanism is suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration measurements to date, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. This study adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most significant evolutionary events in the history of life. The molecular consequences of this transition are still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the loss of genes, which is in turn linked to the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the impact of climate change on water security. We use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% by the year 2100 under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of regional climate models in assessing the impact of climate change on regional water resources. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the discovery of quasicrystals in the laboratory has been much slower. This is because the synthesis of quasicrystals requires the application of extreme pressure and temperature, conditions that are difficult to achieve. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes. We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages ameliorated the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), whereas only the later stage was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. It is also the first to report evidence on the extent to which individual differences in sensitivity to negative information may account for this pattern. Results suggest that the extent to which people react more strongly to negative information is a cross-national phenomenon, but that individual differences in sensitivity to negative information may account for some of this variation. Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which is mutated in Stormorken syndrome, result in constitutive activation of the store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) channel. We also report that mutations in the pore-forming protein of the SOCE channel, ORAI1, result in a similar phenotype in zebrafish. These data expand our understanding of the molecular function of the SOCE channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We show that aggregates cause non–cell-autonomous pathology, including loss of vulnerable neurons. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in the brain and a framework for understanding the mechanisms of neurodegeneration in several major neurodegenerative diseases. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, and the presence of these inclusions is a key diagnostic feature of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions are composed of proteins that are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners. This suggests that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a mechanism for the formation of inclusions in ALS and may lead to the development of therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The earliest known angiosperms are poorly known. The study of Montsechia, first recovered from the Pyrenees of Spain in the 1910s, has been poorly understood in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. Lower Cretaceous aquatic angiosperms, such as Archaefructus and Montsechia, open the possibility that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. Sea level is rising, and it is rising because of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise, which is important for understanding the impacts of sea level rise and for assessing the validity of climate models. The study also provides a new estimate of the rate of climate change, which is important for understanding the causes of sea level rise.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the causes of the increase in pain are not well understood. We show that pain is not increasing with age in the United States, as is commonly assumed, but is instead increasing with education, with tomorrow’s elderly being sicker than today’s elderly.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of enzyme active sites has the potential to provide a detailed picture of structure and reactivity, including the location of hydrogen atoms and the tautomeric states of key species. Here, this approach is used to study the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, highlighting the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to study enzyme mechanisms. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus infection with a high case fatality rate. There is a pressing need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral replication that has shown efficacy in vitro against MERS-CoV. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection prevented disease and reduced virus replication and lung pathology. These data support the development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses. This study also highlights the potential of remdesivir as a treatment for other viruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This article is protected by copyright. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin, which is catabolized by hemocytes only at night. This glycan is provided just before dusk, when the squid’s symbiotic organ is at its most metabolically active. We propose that this strategy may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbial communities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that a brief, online intervention can reduce suspension rates by half. It also shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships is a powerful predictor of student behavior. Finally, it shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to reduce suspension rates and for the design of schools.

DNA alkylation is a major cause of mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these outcomes. Increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering operations is one way to reduce the environmental impact of the food system. However, the impact of this type of intervention has not been systematically studied. Here, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 78.8%. This is equivalent to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 78.8%. This is a large effect and demonstrates the potential for simple interventions to have a large impact on the environment. This study provides evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to the cell surface of a collection of some 700 surface proteins in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cells stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic is the most devastating in a century. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is unknown. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is likely to be important for immune evasion and/or immune suppression. The structure also reveals a unique noncovalent interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is likely to be important for immune suppression. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are “strong”—that is, that have a large effect size. But how do we assess the strength of an association? This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the formation of vascular networks. However, the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs has not been achieved. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells from nonvascular cells using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). This study provides a promising approach for the generation of ECs and the formation of vascular networks. Furthermore, the ETV2-induced ECs can be transplanted into ischemic mice, which can improve blood flow recovery. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are implicated in cancer and other diseases. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that augmentor ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. Deficiency in augmentor ligands results in strong impairment in iridophore patterning of embryonic and adult zebrafish that is phenocopied in zebrafish deficient in Ltk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system for understanding the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo. It also provides a foundation for understanding the function of augmentor ligands in vivo. Finally, it provides a foundation for understanding the function of Alk and Ltk in human diseases. This study is a first step toward understanding the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS. STING-βKO mice had decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8. STING-βKO mice also exhibited down-regulation of Pax6 messenger RNA and protein levels and loss of nuclear localization. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Our study provides a molecular mechanism for STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and contributes to the understanding of the role of STING in the pathogenesis of T2D. These findings may provide a new perspective for the development of STING-targeted therapies for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, the human and avian influenza viruses. The avian influenza viruses are divided into three subtypes, A/chicken/Australia/3001/97 (H5N1), A/chicken/Vietnam/1203/97 (H5N2), and A/chicken/Vietnam/1081/97 (H5N3). These viruses are highly pathogenic and can cause severe human infections. The H5N1 virus is currently the most dangerous. The mechanism by which the viral genome is packaged into the viral particles is unknown. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an H5N1 virus. This interaction is sequence specific and favors copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key factor that promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms by which the disturbed flow promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions remain largely unknown. Here, we report that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is critical for the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the disturbed flow in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and identifies YAP/TAZ as a potential therapeutic target for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a rationale for the development of athero-protective therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfires are a natural and important part of many ecosystems. However, in the United States, human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfires, increasing the risk of fire to people, property, and ecosystems. This expansion has been driven by the increasing number of people living and working in areas prone to wildfires. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires relative to lightning-caused wildfires. Our results highlight the importance of reducing fire risk in areas where human-caused wildfires are dominant.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropod pests remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropod pests, which should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help to understand the arthropod–plant adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection are likely important. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the time between cell infection and viral production, the rate of viral production, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus. We also estimate the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. We assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can inform the design of clinical trials of antiviral treatments for ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a major threat to the health of coral reefs worldwide. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is accompanied by a loss of the reef-building capacity of corals. However, the mechanisms underlying the onset of bleaching are poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. This process forms a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the stability of the coral holobiont and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of the interplay between intestinal tumors, the microbiome, and host homeostasis. It also identifies a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal tumors. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. This enhanced expression of ROR1 was associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. Furthermore, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of deglaciation was preceded by a unique, ∼192-y series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes similar to those associated with modern ozone depletion over Antarctica. These changes occurred exactly at the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation, suggesting that the Mount Takahe eruptions were the cause. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can influence climate and the atmosphere, and thus the Earth system, on timescales much shorter than the geologic record. This is important for understanding the potential impacts of future volcanic eruptions on climate and the atmosphere. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of ecosystem services. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries. Our data can be used to inform conservation, fishery management, and food security planning.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the dendrite and is dependent on sensory activity, calcium signaling, and the activity of a kinase that is normally involved in restricting dendrite growth. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for the discovery of new genes involved in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate may be a more general feature of the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. It is also highly variable, with some regions of the genome recombining at a high rate, whereas others do so at a low rate. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination rates across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions of the genome recombining at a high rate, whereas others do so at a low rate. The distribution of recombination rates is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the distribution of recombination rates in plants may be conserved from the earliest stages of evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The rest of the activity is metabolic, and this is the focus of this study. We used metabolic PET to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. In healthy subjects, the dominant (first component) metabolic RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. PD patients showed reduced deactivation of the “DMN-like” dominant metabolic RSN, which was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, the best studied modification is the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification of transfer RNAs. In this study, we describe a 5′ NAD+ cap in yeast. This cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally and is not found on pre-mRNAs. This discovery expands the number of cap structures in eukaryotes and raises the possibility that the 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This work provides a model for the evolution of cap structures in eukaryotes. (Show more)

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here, we show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells from people with diabetes persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). These DNA-me differences are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Our results may help to identify new targets for the prevention and treatment of diabetes complications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This study may also provide a platform for the development of new therapeutic strategies for TNBC. This article

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high prevalence and a high rate of relapse. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and in the behavioral symptoms of the disorder. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also opens the door to the study of the role of the gut microbiota in other psychiatric disorders.

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of many plant species. In some species, such as tomato, the production of nitrogenous volatiles is highly specialized and restricted to a few compounds. In others, such as Nicotiana benthamiana, the production of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles is a general feature. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the identification of the enzymes involved is a major step forward in understanding the chemistry of these compounds and their regulation during fruit ripening. This study describes the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor. This study provides a major step forward in understanding the chemistry and regulation of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of biodiversity conservation and climate change mitigation strategies. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a hub of the hippocampal circuit, which is critical for spatial memory. The organization of MEC is important for understanding the functional architecture of the circuit. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are critical for place-cell firing to be grid aligned, are anatomically distinct from other neurons. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC and its relation to the hippocampus. They also provide a platform for future studies of the functional organization of the circuit. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of flowering regulation in a parasitic plant. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a unique type of synapse between striatonigral fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites in the nigrostriatal system. We call these formations “striosome–dendron bouquets” and show that they are present in the brains of mice and humans. The striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study provides a model for the study of the organization of the nigrostriatal system and its dysfunction in human disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection. But how do we know when we are connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by people to gauge their own connection, and by listeners to gauge the connection between two people. This signal is also used to predict the quality of the connection between two people and the connection between two people and a third party. We propose that this signal is a fundamental part of how we connect with each other.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells (SANCs) are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels, key components of store-operated Ca2+ entry, are selectively expressed in SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest, in wild-type rice but not in plants with altered expression of jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis and perception genes. This interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores was associated with priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect rice against insect pests. This study also provides a model for understanding the interaction between Si and JA in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of other lipids in macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of lipid metabolism in macrophages.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural mechanisms of language are not well understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of synaptic plasticity. This idea is not new, but it has not been explored in the context of language. We show that this mechanism can support the binding of linguistic features over time, the integration of information over space, and the storage of information in memory. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biotechnology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of different DNA nanostructures for their ability to internalize into cells of mature plants, deliver siRNAs, and effectively silence a constitutively expressed gene in Nicotiana benthamiana leaves. We show that nanostructure internalization into plant cells and corresponding gene silencing efficiency depends on the DNA nanostructure size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the nanostructure. We further confirm that the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures correlates with their respective gene silencing efficiencies but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of plant biotechnology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient inputs from small tributaries are often overlooked in assessments of watershed-scale nutrient loading. However, we show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies. We found that small tributaries delivered a disproportionately high amount of dissolved inorganic nutrients to the world’s fifth largest freshwater lake. This suggests that their plumes may become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone, increasing the likelihood of coastal algal blooms. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication and the need for more attention to these systems in future assessments of watershed-scale nutrient loading.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a random force. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of complex systems in general.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic dynamics of cortical microcircuits, which in turn alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes are critical for the development of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same circuit changes may be responsible for the development of seizures in some patients. This work may help to inform the development of new therapies for NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 y. The cause of this warming is still under debate. Here, we present evidence for a global warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 y. We show that this event was accompanied by a rapid increase in atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. The warming event was linked to an increase in organic matter burial and anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that the warming event was linked to enhanced nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. This study provides insights into the potential causes of the current rapid warming event. (Show more)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s leading producer of palm oil. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a panacea for the palm oil industry, but it is an important tool in the fight against deforestation. We hope that our findings will inform the development of future certification schemes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The exocyst complex is a key regulator of the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits. The function of the exocyst complex is conserved from yeast to humans. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates. In many species, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In others, sex is determined by multiple interacting loci. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination loci in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple loci can produce a modular system of sex-linked traits, which can be further modified by the acquisition of a new sex determination allele. This system of modular traits provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This study provides a model for understanding the effects of multiple interacting loci on the evolution of sex determination. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and Fe is a key redox factor. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoid lipofuscin) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that Fe levels in the retina are tightly regulated and that Fe-mediated oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E was required for the photoinduced toxicity of the retina. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that Fe chelation may be a useful strategy for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

Predator specialization is a fundamental process in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophore specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have directly evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our findings suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. The evolutionary history of siphonophore specialization helps build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The study of the hominin hand is complicated by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the metabolic reprogramming that accompanies cancer is a major focus of cancer research. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic regulator, converting serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective in cell-based assays. Finally, we show that formate can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer. The world is facing a food crisis, and the agricultural sector is the main driver of this crisis. However, little is known about the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s diets and vitamin A adequacy, and that forest fragmentation can increase people’s diets and vitamin A adequacy. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also provides a framework for future research on the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased agricultural productivity, but at the cost of increased vehicle weight. This has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, which now exceeds safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map of subsoil compaction susceptibility, based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the recent discovery of a 100-m-long, 10-m-wide, and 3-m-deep, 150-million-year-old, fossilized footprint in the Morrison Formation of Colorado.
